intro: Allium hookeri, commonly known as the purple garlic or hooker's onion, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the mountainous regions of Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and clusters of pale purple to pink flowers. The plant produces small, round bulbs that are often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb. Its botanical features include a fibrous root system and a short, stout stem that supports its flowering spikes. Allium hookeri thrives in well-drained soil and prefers full sun to partial shade.
